For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: Yes, Yes, Yes correct

The given answers are correct.

Hello everyone - im missing comments here ;-)

My opinion:

comments.content: I agree. #2 is instant; keyword is "manually"
A task completed for tigger an instant flow.

I think point 2 refers to the back end of the system/process hence its automated.

Users manually send email but how the email is process is automated

Correct point 2 is instant.

Automated flows Create an automation that is triggered by an event such as arrival of an email from a specific person, or a mention of your company in social media.

Instant flows Start an automation with a click of a button. You can automate for repetitive tasks from your Desktop or Mobile devices. For example, instantly send a reminder to the team with a push of a button from your mobile device. 

Scheduled flows Schedule an automation such as daily data upload to SharePoint or a database.


Business process flows provide a guide for people to get work done. They provide a streamlined user experience that leads people through the processes their organization has defined for interactions that need to be advanced to a conclusion of some kind.

discussion.content: Point-2 should be instant

-Business process
-instant
-scheduled
Look at the first part of question 170 (next question to this one). It contradicts the second part of this question.

Answer is correct. Second answer is automated because it is called whenever a task is completed.. so imagine it to be an approval process..its not called upon demand by a click of a button but only during an IF condition in an automated workflow
Second one is INSTANT. Manual is the opposite of automatic.
Answer is correct. #2 is Automated because an Automated flow has a trigger to perform an action when a task is completed. An Instant Flow does not have that trigger as an option

Bussiness process
Instant

Business Process
Instant
Scheduled
2 is instant.. Instant flows starts with manual trigger. Ex: button clicked by user

Number 2 is Instant: 

"Triggers for instant/manual flows
If you'd like to run a cloud flow with a tap of a button on your mobile device, to remind your team to join the daily team meeting, create an instant flow (button flow). You can trigger these flows manually from any device."

"Triggers for automated flows
If you'd like to create a cloud flow that performs tasks automatically after an event, for example, create a cloud flow that notifies you by email when someone tweets keyword you specify, create an automated flow."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/triggers-introduction

Manually=! auto.
-Business process
-scheduled
-automated

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A project deadline is approaching. The project manager reports that there are still a number of critical tasks that are not complete.
You need to implement Power Automate to help streamline processes.
Which types of flows should you use? To answer, drag the appropriate flow types to the correct requirement. Each flow type may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

questions.answer_description:
All the app versions created in last six months will be kept.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/restore-an-app
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have version 1.0.0.0 of a published Power Apps app. You create and publish version 2.0.0.0 of the app. A customer goes through the process of restoring the previous version of the app.
How many versions of the app are displayed in the Version tab for the app? To answer, select the appropriate option in the answer area.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Hey liberator, you're correct as this question is same as Question 1,here on ExamTopics. 
3 is the answer,
Question doesn't say that restoring has been done but that the customer is going through the process of restoring and in that process he will see two versions.

discussion.content: 3. Provided versions 1.0.0.0.0 and 2.0.0.0.0 are both less than 6 months, the version restored by the customer will be saved as version 3.0.0.0.0 which means there will now be 3 versions

I agree with Libertoo's argument. 
You start with the original version (1)
You then create a new 2.0.0.0 version (2)
When you create a restore copy (3) of that (2.0.0.0) version, you will end up with 3 copies in total. 
The provided answer is incorrect and misleading, examtopics needs to correct this its misleading

I think 2, hear me out. 
Yes, a customer can restore a previous version of a Power Apps app, but there are some conditions to be aware of. Only the app owner can restore a version of an app. If a customer needs to restore a version, they must be set as the owner of the app. Additionally, you can only restore app versions created in the last six months. The question do not mention granting owner privileges to the customer.

2 IS correct. "Only the app owner can restore a version of an app. To set a user as the owner of an app, use the Power Apps cmdlets for administrators" https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/restore-an-app

comments.content: same context in question 1 and it says 3 so i will stay with 3
yes, it says the process is ongoing, so it has to be 2...

discussion.content: I hate these trick questions and answers, now I need to re-learn english, I think it is 2, as the restore process is ongoing... both previous versions are PUBLISHED...
Clearly there is a problem here as this is the same question as question #1 yet a different answer

2, because being in the process of restoring it doesn't mean you have already restored it . and as it stands now in the version tab you only see 2, after you restore it there will be 3. But the the answer is 2.

A CUSTOMER CANNOT create new restores. if you read carefully is the customer who wants to make a new restore not the app owner. -"only the app owner can restore a version of an app. To set a user as the owner of an app, use the Power Apps cmdlets for administrators."- ANSWER IS 2. since is the customer who DO NOT HAVE PRIVILEGES AS APP OWNER who wants to make a new restore which will not ALLOW. so the customer will still see only 2 versions of the app. ANSWER IS 2. 
The answer is in the official doc from the purple notes: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/restore-an-app

A CUSTOMER CANNOT create new restores. if you read carefully is the customer who wants to make a new restore not the app owner. "If the app that you want to restore doesn't appear, make sure that you're in the right environment."
The answer is in the official doc from the purple notes: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/restore-an-app

comments.content: ANSWER IS 2 since is the customer is the one who wants to create a restore. not the app owner.
Sorry this is the right purple note from the doc: "only the app owner can restore a version of an app. To set a user as the owner of an app, use the Power Apps cmdlets for administrators."

discussion.content: The correct answer is 3 1.0.0.0, 2.0.0.0 and 3.0.0.0

n the scenario you described, where you have version 1.0.0.0 of a published Power Apps app and you create and publish version 2.0.0.0 of the app, two versions of the app are created:

Version 1.0.0.0: This is the initial version of the app that you had published.

Version 2.0.0.0: This is the new version of the app that you created and published.

So, there are a total of two versions of the app. If a customer restores the previous version (version 1.0.0.0), it would replace the current version (version 2.0.0.0) with the previous one.
Answer is 3 : As publish version 2.0.0.0 of the app is there and customer restored the previous version of the app ie version 1.0.0.0. which again create a new version(" ") on restoring.
restoring app create a new version of the app, so the answer it's 3 --> https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/restore-an-app
it stated that he only goes to the process of restoring but it didnt said that he restored it so the answer is 2

The question didnt say the user has restored the previous version, it says the user goes through the process, which are two different cases. The answer is two versions as the user will see only version 1.0.0.0.0 and 2.0.0.0.0 (the live version) as the user is yet to restore version 1.0.0.0.0
The answer should be Option C. Three as two will be published and one will be restore so in total 2 + 1 = 3
there's a similar question (#1 in page 1) and there the answer is three. this is so confusing.

Two versions of the app will be displayed in the Version tab. The first version (1.0.0.0) is the previously published version, and the second version (2.0.0.0) is the latest version that was published. The customer can choose to restore either version of the app from the Version tab.
Absolutelyu the Answer is 3.
Shouldn't it be 3 versions?

comments.content: The first question of this exam stated it was three versions. I agree it is three versions. You have your initial version, your published version, then a new version that was recovered. Three total.

discussion.content: From the first Question of this exam we read that we can see only two versions after restoring the old version. So the answer should be two.
It is clear that there are only two versions according to question, version 2.0.0.0
still appearing in the exam 16/03/2023
appeared in the exam 2/27/2023
3 is the correct answer.

i understand this question that he didn't restore the pervious version ,so he will see 2 versions ,from the statement .
"A customer goes through the process of restoring the previous version of the app."
any comment appreciated!
It is 100% 3. Saw it on a practice exam through Pearson
3. It is demostrated in above question.

comments.content: Incorrect. From the previously mentioned link (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-apps/restore-an-app), see steps 7 & 8.

discussion.content: I believe they are 2 because it doesn't make sense for the client to be able (even indirectly) to create a new version in the app. He restoring, will go back to the previous version will not create another.
With the given info, it should be 3

Depends on how you look at things, it's poorly described:
"A customer goes through the process of restoring the previous version of the app."

App 1.0.0.0.0 = version 1
App 2.0.0.0.0 = version 2

If I would go to the restore previous versions, I would see 2 versions.
If I would actually restore the app, it would show 3 versions.

comments.content: A customer goes through the process of restoring the previous version of the app. = New version = 3 versions

discussion.content: Should be 3
Should be 3. the restore creates the 3rd (Live) version
The POwerApp release version might show the restored app version but as a total number of versions available, it would be 3.
True the answer should be 3 and not 2
Correct!
Verified - this appeared on 11/13/2021

1-Instant- Trigger a flow when a button is selected. Choose a Flow type: Instant. Instant flows are triggered by a manual action, such as clicking a button on a mobile device or a web browser. You can use instant flows to perform tasks that require user input or confirmation.
2-Automatic - Trigger a flow when a record is created Choose a Flow type: Automatic. Automatic flows are triggered by an event or a condition, such as when a record is created, updated, or deleted in a data source. You can use automatic flows to perform tasks that do not require user interaction.
3 - Business Process Flow - Guide a user through a series of steps Choose a Flow type: Business Process Flow. Business process flows are triggered by a user who wants to follow a predefined process or a workflow, such as a sales cycle or a customer service request. You can use business process flows to provide a guided and consistent user experience that leads to a desired outcome.
Answere are correct
Correct
correct

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are creating a number of Power Automate flows.
You need to select the triggers for the flows.
Which flow types should you use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Formula -
Reading an Excel document retrieves the data from the document, allowing it to be processed and modified in flows.
Read and extract data from an Excel document with the Read from Excel worksheet action.

Box 2: Connector -
Azure Data Lake Store connector allows you to read and add data to an Azure Data Lake account.
The Azure Data Lake connector is available for Power Automate.

Box 3: Expression -
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/pad-excel-automation/3-reading-excel-document https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/connectors/azuredatalake/

comments.content: No matter the aim, to access the services you need a connector.

discussion.content:
Microsoft Excel: Connector
"Use a connector to import data from a selection of many different sources, such as Microsoft Excel, Azure, SQL Server database, SharePoint, Access, OData, and more."
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/data-platform/data-platform-import-export

Data Lake: Connector
"Azure Data Lake Store connector allows you to read and add data to an Azure Data Lake account."
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/connectors/azuredatalake/

GitHub: Connector
"With GitHub Connector, you can create a GitHub repo, create a pull request, merge a pull request, compare commits, trigger a GitHub actions workflow and much more from Power Apps and Power Automate."
https://powerapps.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/github-connector-features-for-power-platform/
Connector, Connector, Connector

Microsoft Excel Connector
Azure Data Lake Connector
GitHub Connector
Connector, Connector, Connector

https://powerapps.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/github-connector-features-for-power-platform/
GITHUB = CONNECTOR
Connector Connector Connector, all are external data sources and all presumably off prem, they all require connectors.

Given answers are correct..." retrieve" data not connected data
Formula etc.. for excel
Connector ...Azura
Expression...Github
I had: Connector, Connector, Expression (the last one was a guess)
